text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zimbabwe press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The Zimbabwe government plans to purchase an additional fleet of over 50 Mercedes Benz cars and an unspecified number of Mazda 626s valued at over U.S.$3 million to boost its fleet for service during the Organisation of African Unity summit scheduled to take place in Harare in June.

- Zimbabwe's major cargo airline, Affretair, is threatened with closure at the end of June after the airline decided it was no longer viable to send its one remaining aircraft for a complete overhaul.

- Negotiations are underway for a reverse take-over of FMB Holdings Ltd by a black-owned Zimbabwean financial institution in what is seen as a move to bolster First Merchant Bank Zimbabwe Ltd 's faltering market share under stiff competition.
- The price of petrol, diesel and other petroleum products went up as of midnight on Thursday by between 12 and 24 percent, three months after the last increases.
- The Vehicle Inspection Depot in Harare has stopped accepting new applications for driving tests until September when it hopes to have cleared a backlog of about 11,000 people.
- Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila flew into Zimbabwe on Thursday for talks with President Robert Mugabe on the situation in his country.
